title: Nick Candy-backed Satellite Solutions Worldwide buys French satellite broadband provider
text:
0.0001 0.0000 
Oxfordshire-based Satellite Solutions Worldwide (LSE: CLEE.L - news ) is buying Sat2Way to target a potential one million French homes without fast internet connectivity 
An AIM company backed by billionaire property developer Nick Candy is buying a major French satellite broadband provider to bolster its position in the growing market of providing high-speed internet to remote areas. 
Oxfordshire-based Satellite Solutions Worldwide (SSW), which joined AIM in May via a reverse takeover of cash shell Cleeve Capital, targets customers in the “digital divide”, who have no internet connectivity or poor coverage. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is now acquiring French provider Sat2Way SARL for €825,000 in cash for 100pc of the share capital. 
SSW, in which Mr Candy has a 10.9pc stake, specialises in rural, last-mile and emergency communications via satellite, delivering internet to areas where traditional broadband services cannot. 
Founded in 2008, it rents satellite capacity from European companies Eutelsat (Paris: FR0010221234 - news ) , SES and Avanti, then sells the necessary equipment and broadband tariff to customers. 
SSW is already part of a government pilot scheme in the UK to deliver broadband to 1,000 rural homes and businesses in Scotland and Northern Ireland (Other OTC: IRLD - news ) . 
It now sees opportunity to grow earnings by expanding into France, where the Government is subsidising satellite broadband as a solution for the nearly one million homes with slow or non-existent internet connections. 
As a result of the acquisition SSW will become the second largest satellite broadband provider in France, with more than 6,500 subscribers. 
SSW has expanded quickly since it listed, with the new acquisition increasing its customer base to 20,000, up 65pc since May. 
In July SSW acquired the customer base of Irish satellite broadband provider Onwave Ltd and this month it signed an agreement to work with telecommunications operator Gigaclear to identify households without access to fibre or fast broadband. 
Chief executive Andrew Walwyn said: “We are delighted to welcome Sat2Way customers and staff to SSW. 
"This is our third acquisition in a key European market since listing on AIM in May 2015; it underpins our growth ambitions and takes our subscriber base to approximately 20,000 customers, a 65% increase since float." 
In April Mr Candy, who runs luxury property company Candy & Candy with his brother Christian , invested in Audioboom, an audio sharing service. He is married to former pop star and Neighbours actress Holly Valance. 
Mr Candy is the second largest shareholder in SSW after the company’s chief executive Andrew Walwyn. Former Leeds United boss Chris Akers also holds 3.7pc of SSW share capital via his company Sports Resource Group Ltd.
